text: Seat belts must be fastened during {{c1::movement on the surface (taxi)}}, {{c2::takeoff}}, and {{c3::landing}}.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT A (uspa.org)

text: The wind comes from {{c1::ahead}} initially upon exit from the aircraft.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT A (uspa.org)

text:
Landing priorities are:
A: {{c1::Land with the wing level and flying in a straight line}}
B: {{c2::Land in a clear and open area, avoiding obstacles}}
C: {{c3::Flare to at least the half-brake position}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT A (uspa.org)

text:
Procedure for a hard landing (parachute landing fall or PLF):
  • {{c1::feet and knees together}}
  • {{c2::hands and elbows in}}
  • {{c3::roll on landing}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT A (uspa.org)

text: In the event of a canopy problem, students should decide and act about executing emergency procedures by {{c1::2,500}} feet.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT B (uspa.org)

text:
How would you address closed end cells during opening?

{{c1::Pull toggles to flare position and hold (or pull down rear risers and hold)}} and watch altitude. If stubborn, determine controllability with turn and flare by 2,500 feet.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT B (uspa.org)

text:
How would you address broken lines or other damage?

Determine {{c1::controllability and ability to flare}} by 2,500 feet.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT B (uspa.org)

text:
How would you address a good canopy that isn't turning?

{{c1::Be sure both brakes are released.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT B (uspa.org)

text:
What is the appropriate action if below {{c2::1,000}} feet without a landable parachute?

{{c1::Immediately deploy the reserve parachute}}, but not below 1,000 feet with an SOS system.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT B (uspa.org)

text:
If the pilot chute goes over the front of the canopy after it has opened, how can you tell if it’s a malfunction?

It is probably safe to land if the canopy {{c1::flares and turns correctly.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT B (uspa.org)

text:
What is the correct response to an open container in freefall using a hand-deployed system?

{{c1::No more than two tries or two seconds to locate and deploy the main pilot chute}}; if no success, cut away and deploy the reserve.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT B (uspa.org)

text:
What do you do if the pilot chute extracts the deployment bag from the parachute container but the deployment bag fails to release the parachute canopy for inflation?

{{c1::Cut away and deploy the reserve.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT B (uspa.org)

text:
What do you do if part of the deployed parachute is caught on the jumper or the equipment (horseshoe)?

{{c1::Cut away and deploy the reserve.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT B (uspa.org)

text: The three legs of the canopy landing pattern with relation to the wind direction are {{c1::downwind (with the wind)}}, {{c2::base (across the wind but downwind of the target)}}, {{c3::and final (into the wind)}}.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT B (uspa.org)

text:
Why is it undesirable to land off the end of a runway?

{{c1::Approaching and departing aircraft.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT B (uspa.org)

text: In flat and stable freefall at terminal velocity, an average jumper will fall {{c2::1,000}} feet every {{c1::5.5}} seconds.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT C (uspa.org)

text:
What is the correct procedure for recovering from instability to the belly-to-earth position?

{{c1::Altitude, arch, legs, relax.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT C (uspa.org)

text:
Is it better to pull at the planned altitude or to fall lower to get stable before pulling?

{{c1::Pull at the planned altitude, regardless of stability.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT C (uspa.org)

text: The purpose of the wave-off before deployment is to {{c1::signal to other jumpers}}.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT C (uspa.org)

text:
What part of the landing pattern is most dangerous to skydivers?

{{c1::The intersection of the base and final approach legs.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT C (uspa.org)

text:
How do higher wind speeds affect the planned landing pattern as compared to the pattern plan for a calm day?
  • Places the planned pattern entry point {{c1::farther upwind}}
  • Lengthens the {{c2::downwind leg}}
  • {{c3::Shortens}} the base leg
  • {{c4::Shortens}} the final approach
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT C (uspa.org)

text:
In moderately strong winds, how far downwind of an obstacle would you expect to find turbulence?

{{c1::10-20 times the height of the obstacle.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT C (uspa.org)

text:
What is the best procedure to use when flying your canopy in turbulent conditions?

{{c1::Keep the canopy flying in a straight line at full flight (or as directed by the owner’s manual).}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT C (uspa.org)

text:
Why is it important to protect your parachute system operation handles when in and around the aircraft?

{{c1::Keeps them in place and prevents accidental or premature deployment.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT C (uspa.org)

text:
What is the equipment pre-flight strategy to use before putting on your gear?

{{c1::Top to bottom, back to front.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT C (uspa.org)

text: The three-ring main canopy release system disconnects {{c2::the main parachute from the harness}} by pulling {{c1::the cables to release the cloth loop.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT C (uspa.org)

text:
How do you know if a reserve parachute has been packed by an FAA rigger within the last 180 days?

{{c1::Information found on the reserve packing data card.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT C (uspa.org)

text:
How do you know the reserve container has not been opened since the FAA rigger last closed it?

{{c1::Rigger’s packing seal on the reserve ripcord.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT C (uspa.org)

text: If the surface winds are blowing from west to east, you will face {{c1::east}} to fly the {{c2::downwind}} leg of the landing pattern.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT C (uspa.org)

text: Wing loading is calculated by dividing {{c1::the exit weight by the square footage or the canopy.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT C (uspa.org)

text: With the same wing loading, a {{c2::smaller}} canopy of the same model will exhibit more {{c1::lively}} performance characteristics.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT C (uspa.org)

text:
When to attempt a stand-up landing:
  • {{c1::when you’re in control of all the variables}}
  • {{c2::after a good flare at the appropriate altitude}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT C (uspa.org)

text: For planned deployment initiation at 3,000 feet, an average-sized jumper should fall for approximately {{c1::15}} seconds after exiting at 5,000 feet.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text:
What is the most appropriate response to loss of heading control in freefall?

{{c1::Altitude, arch, legs, relax.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text:
What is the best way to avoid a canopy collision when turning?

{{c1::Look first in the direction of the turn.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text:
What is the quickest and safest way to change heading immediately after opening?

{{c1::Rear riser turn with the brakes still set.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text:
How would you steer a parachute that has a broken brake line?

{{c1::Release both brakes and use the back risers to steer.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text:
How would you prepare to land a canopy using the rear risers to flare?

{{c1::Practice with rear-riser flares at altitude with that canopy during a routine jump.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text:
What is the procedure for landing on a building?
  1. {{c1::Disconnect the RSL (if time)}}
  2. {{c2::Contact the building feet first}}
  3. {{c3::PLF}}
  4. {{c4::Cut away}}
  5. Wait for competent help
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text: The purpose of the automatic activation device (AAD) is to {{c1::back up the jumper’s emergency procedures.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text:
What is the "check of threes"?
  • check {{c1::three-ring release system}} for {{c4::correct assembly and RSL}}
  • check three points of {{c2::harness attachment for snap assembly or correct routing and adjustment}}
  • check {{c3::three operation handles: main activation, cutaway, reserve}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text:
What must the spotter do to determine what is directly underneath the aircraft while on jump run?

{{c1::Place head completely outside the aircraft and look straight down.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text:
How far horizontally must jumpers be from any cloud below 10,000 feet MSL?

{{c1::2,000 feet}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text:
How far horizontally must jumpers be from any cloud at 10,000 feet MSL and above?

{{c1::one mile}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text: The minimum {{c3::visibility}} requirement below {{c1::10,000}} feet MSL is {{c2::three}} miles.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text:
What are the minimum visibility requirements at and above 10,000 feet MSL?

{{c1::five miles}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text:
Who is responsible for a jumper observing cloud clearance requirements?

{{c1::Jumper and pilot}}.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text:
According to the BSRs, what is the latest a student may jump?

{{c1::All student jumps must be completed by sunset.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text:
What is the technique for determining the point straight below the aircraft during jump run?

{{c1::Determine two lines from the horizon, one ahead and one abreast, and find the intersection of those two lines.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text: Jumpers must look for {{c1::clouds and other aircraft}} below before exiting the aircraft.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT D (uspa.org)

text: A jumper's fall rate {{c1::increases}} when performing rolls, loops, or other freeflying maneuvers.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
What happens to a visual altimeter when it's in the jumper's burble?

{{c1::Reads unreliably.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
What is the best way to recover from a stall to full glide?
   
{{c1::Smoothly raise the controls.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
Describe an aerodynamic stall as it applies to a ram-air canopy?

Stable state of decreased {{c1::glide}} and increased {{c2::rate of descent}}.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
When does a dynamic stall occur?

{{c1::At the end of a flare when the jumper begins to rock back under the canopy.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
What happens after a dynamic stall if the tail is held lower than the nose?

{{c1::Full stall.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
What is the best way to determine a canopy's optimum flare speed and depth for landing?

{{c1::Practice different rates of flare entry at different depths of flare.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
Describe your procedure for landing in high winds?
  1. {{c1::Stay well downwind of any obstacle}}
  2. {{c2::Face into the wind early}}
  3. {{c3::Disconnect the RSL}}
  4. {{c4::Land with a PLF}}
  5. {{c5::Pull one toggle down completely}}
  6. {{c6::After landing, cut away if necessary}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text: A nine-cell canopy has {{c1::ten}} A-lines.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
To what part of the canopy do the steering lines (brake lines) connect?

{{c1::tail or trailing edge}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
What lines go through the rear slider grommets?

{{c1::C, D, and brakes}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
Where does the main pilot chute bridle attach to the canopy?

{{c1::top center}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
Who may pack a main parachute?
  • {{c1::FAA rigger}}
  • {{c2::person jumping the parachute}}
  • {{c3::person under rigger's supervision}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text: The main and reserve parachutes need to be packed every {{c1::180}} days.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
Who is in command of the aircraft?

{{c1::pilot}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
What are two purposes for wearing seat belts in an aircraft?
  • {{c1::to maintain the correct balance}}
  • {{c2::protection in a crash}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text: The {{c1::pilot}} is responsible for ensuring that the aircraft is in condition for safe flight.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text: The pilot of an unpressurized aircraft is required to breathe supplemental oxygen at {{c1::14,000}} feet MSL and above.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text: All occupants of an unpressurized aircraft must be provided with supplemental oxygen at and above {{c1::15,000}} feet MSL.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
In an aircraft with the exit door near the back, what must jumpers do to maintain the balance during exit procedures?

{{c1::Remain forward until it is time for their group to exit.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
What is the biggest danger to a jumper when flying the canopy pattern?

{{c1::other canopies}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
What is the best way to avoid a canopy collision?

{{c1::See and remain clear of other jumpers.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text: The RSL works by forming a {{c1::separable link between the main riser and reserve ripcord}} so that {{c2::cutting away the main activates the reserve, (if the RSL is hooked up).}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
What would happen if the main riser attached to the RSL breaks?

{{c1::The reserve deploys with the main still attached by the other riser.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
What is the best way to prevent risers from breaking?

{{c1::Inspection and maintenance; correct packing, tight line stowage, and stable deployment, all to prevent hard openings.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
What is one way to prevent a dual deployment?

{{c1::Initiate malfunction procedures high enough to cut away safely and avoid AAD activation.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
What is generally the best action to take in the biplane two-canopy-out scenario?

{{c1::Release the brakes on the front canopy only and steer that canopy gently; PLF.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
What is generally the best action to take in the side-by-side two-canopy-out scenario?

{{c1::Release the brakes on the dominant canopy only and steer that canopy gently; or release the RSL (if time) and cut away; PLF.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
What is generally the best action to take in the downplane two-canopy-out scenario?

{{c1::Release the RSL (if time) and cut away.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT E (uspa.org)

text:
What is the best way to change the direction of canopy flight while conserving the most altitude?

{{c1::Braked turns.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text:
What happens if a canopy is controlled too deeply in brakes?

{{c1::It stalls.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text:
Describe the difference between flaring from half brakes and full glide?

Flaring from half brakes requires a {{c1::quicker}} stroke, the stroke is {{c2::shorter}}, and stalls occur {{c3::sooner}}.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text:
How does the half-braked position affect the canopy's flight?

{{c1::Slows descent, changes glide.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text:
How is heading corrected during a track?

{{c1::Turn head slightly towards direction of the turn.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text:
When making tracking jumps from a large plane, why is it important to track perpendicular to the jump run?

{{c1::To avoid other groups ahead and behind.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text: The ground speed of a jump aircraft with an airspeed of {{c2::90}} knots when flying against a 50-knot headwind on jump run is {{c1::40}} knots.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text:
How can jumpers assure adequate separation between groups exiting the aircraft?

{{c1::Gauge separation according to position over the ground.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text:
What are the three most important aspects of packing the main canopy?
  • {{c1::lines straight and in place in the center}}
  • {{c2::slider up}}
  • {{c3::tight line stows}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text: The RSL is routed correctly when there is a clear path from {{c1::the snap shackle to guide ring.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text: The minimum pull altitude allowed for student skydivers and A license holders is {{c1::3,000}} feet.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text: The maximum wind speed allowed for student skydivers is {{c1::14}} mph.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text: A jumper falling for one minute through upper winds averaging 30 mph from the west will drift {{c1::1/2}} mile to the {{c2::east}}.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text:
What is the procedure for landing in power lines?
  1. {{c1::avoid the area early during the descent}}
  2. {{c2::minimum braked turn necessary to avoid lines}}
  3. {{c3::land parallel to the wires}}
  4. {{c4::braked landing}}
  5. {{c5::prepare for PLF}}
  6. {{c6::try to touch only one line at a time}}
  7. {{c7::wait for help and confirmation that the power has been turned off and will remain off until recovery operations are complete}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text:
In the event of an aircraft emergency with no students or instructors aboard, who should coordinate procedures between the pilot and the other jumpers on the load?

{{c1::Jumpmaster or spotter.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text:
How many jumps are required for the USPA A license?

{{c1::25}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text:
What does a USPA A license permit a skydiver to do?
  • {{c1::jump without supervision}}
  • {{c2::pack his or her own main parachute}}
  • {{c3::engage in basic group jumps}}
  • {{c4::perform water jumps}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text:
What should an A-licensed jumper do to regain currency after a ten-week period of inactivity?

{{c1::Make at least one jump under the supervision of a USPA instructional rating holder.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text:
What should an A-licensed jumper do to regain currency after a four-month period of inactivity?

{{c1::Make at least one jump beginning in Category D with a USPA AFF Instructor or in Category B with a USPA IAD Static-Line, or Tandem Instructor before proceeding to unsupervised freefall.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT F (uspa.org)

text:
What is the primary directional control when moving forward to dock in freefall?

{{c1::legs}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text: The minimum {{c2::break-off}} altitude for freefall in groups of five or fewer is {{c1::1,500}} feet above planned deployment altitude.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text:
What is the danger of entering a toggle turn too quickly?

{{c1::line twist}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text:
What does a canopy do after completing a maximum input toggle turn?

{{c1::It dives.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text:
The three biggest dangers of a hard toggle turn near the ground are:
  • {{c1::line twist}}
  • {{c2::collision with jumpers}}
  • {{c3::collision with the ground}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text:
What are the first things to do in the event of a collision and entanglement with another jumper?

{{c1::Check altitude and establish communication.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text: {{c1::Bridle routing and placement}} are the most critical aspects of closing the main container equipped with a hand-deployed pilot chute.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text:
Why is it a bad idea to drag the harness and container system when stowing the lines?

{{c1::It causes unnecessary wear on the three-ring release webbing and loops.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text:
When velcro is used on the brake system, why is it a good idea to place your toggles back on the velcro after you land?

{{c1::It covers the hook velcro, which can damage other components, and prevents tangles.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text:
Why is it bad to leave a parachute in the sun?

{{c1::Ultraviolet rays degrade nylon.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text:
What damage could occur from storing a parachute for prolonged periods in a car during the summer?
  • {{c1::shorter life for AAD batteries }}
  • {{c2::stow band degradation}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text:
What happens to velcro touch fastener when it is used frequently?

{{c1::It loses tackiness.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text:
What happens to stiffened tuck flaps that are frequently used?

{{c1::distortion}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text: The {{c1::FAA}} publishes and enforces rules regarding parachute packing and parachute maintenance.
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text:
What may result if recovering altitude (floating up) under a freefall formation?

{{c1::Collision with formation, funnel.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text:
What extra consideration is required when sitting or moving towards an opened door?
  • Check {{c1::your handles before starting to move to the door.}}
  • Be aware of {{c2::your handles near the door.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text:
Why is it important to remain clear of the area directly above and below other jumpers in freefall?

{{c1::To minimize outcome of possible AAD activation or other accidental or unplanned pack opening.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text:
Why is it important to maintain an automatic activation device to the manufacturer's standards?
  • to improve {{c1::their chances for correct operation}}
  • to help prevent {{c2::premature AAD activations}}
  • to comply {{c3::with the law}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text:
What is the correct response to a canopy entanglement with another jumper below 1,000 feet if it appears the two canopies cannot be separated in time for a safe landing?

{{c1::Deploy the reserve (may not be a safe option with an SOS system).}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text:
Describe your procedure for landing in trees:
  1. {{c1::face into the wind}}
  2. {{c2::prepare for PLF}}
  3. {{c3::flare to half brakes}}
  4. {{c4::protect face and under arms}}
  5. {{c5::wait for help}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text: A tall cumulus cloud indicates that {{c1::there are thunderstorms in the area.}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)

text:
What is the most dangerous part of an incoming front for aircraft and skydivers?
  • {{c1::thunderstorms}} in the gust front
  • rapid and significant {{c2::changes in winds}}
back extra: United States Parachute Association > Safety and Training > Skydive School > CAT G (uspa.org)
